title: New Players Should Get One Free Champion
body: Every single time I play with a friend that's new at the game they all say the same thing. "I'm saving up for ____." 9 times out of 10 it's a 6300 champion. It takes them forever to save up for that champion, and in the meantime they have to play free week champions. They end up getting used to a free week champion just long enough for the rotation to change. Really it would go a long way just to give new player a single free champion. It'd probably help with new player retention, too, which is a win for Riot in the long run.

The whole rune system and mastery system makes no sense. None of it makes sense in the context of a MOBA. The purpose of runes were supposed to be customization and a sense of progression. There's not a lot of customization in runes, they're basically mandatory, and there's virtually no feeling of "I did it!" in unlocking a new rune. It's more of a "woo, I'm slightly closer to the standard power of my characters."
Why do they make no sense?

Runes are objective power. Someone with access to runes is objectively stronger than someone who doesn't have access to runes. Additionally the game is balanced around having runes and masteries. There's a lot of variability in summoner level for low levels, which means someone has an advantage that has nothing to do with their ingame skill. As a very extreme example: I once had a level 18 smurf matched up against 5 level 30s, two of which were in diamond. My enemy laner had roughly a BF sword's worth of stats on me from runes alone, let alone another 12 levels' worth of masteries.

Related: You might agree with a [post](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/ZKY7gKtF-riot-can-you-make-jungle-difficulty-scale-with-summoner-level) I made a few weeks ago.

What you're basically saying is someone who has played longer over someone who has not played as long. The person who has played longer will have more runes. And that completely makes sense and is fair. 

If I practice water polo for an hour each day, and swim 2 hours a day, and someone else just practices water polo for half an hour each day, it makes sense that I would have an advantage in a game over them, no?

Bad analogy. If you practice water polo more than someone else you aren't given fins. If you play chess more than someone should your pawn have more moves available to it? If you play basketball more should you be given a smaller basket?

Playing more means you (hopefully) are more skilled. That's it. You both should start the game on equal footing.

Riot needs to do something about the new player experience PERIOD.  The whole thing stinks.

New player experiece is pretty good tho. They are matched against other new players, NOT SMURFS. 
Let's say you have a friend, he plays for the first time. First 5 levels (coop) work as a placement matches. When he finally gets level 5 he's given MMR that compliments his skill against bots. This MMR doesn't change by playing against bots, only against/with real players. It changes VERY rapidly until level 10, based on game performance, so even if smurf tried to cheat the system and play terribly against bots, he would get boosted up very quickly.

This means new players won't see much smurfs, and if they do, these smurfs are just terrible (i mean bronze 5 terrible). But there's one slight problem. If you try to play with your friend together, his MMR (say 0-300) and yours (1500+) are calculated together and you face enemies with your skill level. If you manage to win and carry that friend, one game is enough to give him like +500 MMR, just because he's low level and he won against superior players. This means he will be seeing very skilled people and smurfs often.

You can check this normal MMR on pages like Op.GG and such, i couldn't believe what happened to my noob friend's MMR after i played with him...
Oh, and this matchmaking works very well... i was sitting at ~2400 MMR with my smurf since level 20, and i've been regulary playing with/against people with plat/dia/master borders (Meaning they're level 30 and very skilled). Also even in normal blind pick, queue times take up to 20 minutes for this smurf of mine. My "noobish" friend falled down to like 500 MMR and he can find games pretty much instantly, with queue times not longer than 30 seconds.

Edit: one last thing, MMR gains/loses MIGHT be affected by your mastery grade after a game. I've noticed im gaining like 30-40% more MMR when i go S-/S/S+. But that's not confirmed, just a thing i noticed. What IS confirmed is you can GAIN MMR is you LOSE but did very well (S grades) and lose MMR when you win but you got totally carried (Think C and lower)

Wait, you mean make the "Starter Pack" (that doesn't contain all the 450 IP Champions) unneeded? How will Riot make their money? 

The community knows that these guys are flat broke, because why on Earth would they even feel the need to explain why Riot needs money for the things they do. 

We're talking about a company that can't even afford a second server for a country, one for the east and the other for the west. We're talking about a company that finds it hard to believe that advertising that there are three champs they can get for free by following them on Facebook, Youtube, and Twitter and get them easy skins. 

Even with this limited amount of money, they always come though. They took the time and resources to make Dominion for us, and allow us the privilege of free RP for playing a tournament we have to win in order to get said amount. They even made a separate map of ARAM, with completely new turrets and everything.

Its also unfair to call them cheap, not when they have to take time to get ready for the LC$ and other events. They finally have a shop open for awesome shirts, knick-knacks, posters, and more. And when you want to be fancy, you can spend some money on a better (or rare) look for you favorite champion (before the meta picks a new one for you).

Luckily we get to play a free game, and have the option to buy champions out of Influence Points. And look how colorful the whole cast is. We have weirdos, freaks, heroes, a king, a demon, and even a talking fish. All you have to do is play for years to earn and unlock them, or play them whenever they might be free. Oh, and if you want to buy a champion on sale, you can buy them for a cheaper amount of real world cash money. Half off.

And when you finally decide to get Runes, you are tricked into buying lots of Runes you'll never use again after you get better ones from the next teir up. And be sparing with how you use them, because you only have 2 free sheets at first. Spend a extra 6,300 IP for other 18 when you feel like it.

Don't worry that Season 1, 2, and some of season 3 have everything and say it doesn't mean anything, because they're right. Its seriously okay to not have the full champion line-up, nor is it necessary to have any Rune to use for Ranked. If you are a completionist, make sure that your computer is top notch because this game takes a lot out of computers. Battle away for possibly moths at a time. Try and somehow win around 12 matches a day to earn around 1,000 IP a day. Then by about 800 days later, unless Riot has a double or quadruple IP week or something, you'll have the whole champion pool. Then, you can start on your Runes, which will take about another 400 days or so, getting only teir three and the Runes pages. Don't worry, though. Its a free game. You don't need a full champion roster.

Saving up may take awhile, but they get to learn a few basics, maybe save up for a 4800 or 3150 champ, and if they don't like them they can refund and get another when they have enough.  The only problem is that most new people don't know just how limited 3 refunds is, which is why I would suggest giving people 1 refund that refreshes after use over three or four days until they hit level 10 or buy something with RP, at which point they get the standard three.  This would allow for a lot of trial and error to get started.  It could be abused too, but I think it's overall help the new player experience a lot more than it would hinder it.
